statement.tex: Find the equation of the curve passing through origin if the slope of the tangent to the curve at any point $(x,y)$ is equal to the square of the difference of the abscissa and ordinate of the point

options.tex:
%text The required curve satisfies the following condition \[ \qquad\quad \dydx = (y-x)^2 \]
\incorrect The required curve satisfies the following condition \[ \qquad\quad \dydx = y^2 - x^2 \] %
%text The required curve satisfies the following condition \[ \qquad\quad \dydx = y^2 - x^2 \] %

reason.tex: %text Abscissa and ordinate are \underline\text{fancy words} for $x$ and $y$ respectively (as shown below) \[ \qquad\qquad (\overbrace{x}^{\text{Abscissa}}, \overbrace{y}^{\text{Ordinate}} )\] And hence, as per the problem, the required curve satisfies the following the condition \[ \qquad \underbrace{\dydx = (y-x)^2 \text{ or } \dydx = (x-y)^2}_{\text{Either is fine}}\] %

options.tex:
%text Of the following three strategies, \underline\text{strategy $II$} is the best % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{NNl}
\hline & \text{Re-write as} & Solve using \\ \hline I & \dydx + 2yx = y^2 + x^2 & Integrating factor \\ \hline II & \dydx = x^2 \left[\yx^2 - 2\yx + 1 \right] & $ y = vx$ \\ \hline III & \dydx = (y-x)^2 & Let $z = y-x$ \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} %text %

reason.tex:
%text The table below summarizes why the given differential equation \underline\text{is not} a linear or a homogenous differential equation. Hence, it \underline\text{cannot} be solved as those % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{NlN}
\hline \text{If written as} & Looks like & \text{Is not because} \\ \hline \dydx + 2xy = x^2 + y^2 & Linear & \dydx + 2xy \neq F(x) \\ \hline \dydx = x^2 \left[\yx^2 - 2\yx + 1 \right] & Homogenous & \dydx \neq F\yx \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} %text Which leaves \underline\text{strategy $III$} as the best option. So, let us try and work with that%

options.tex:
%text If $z = y-x$ then % \begin{align}
\frac{dz}{z^2-1} &= dx \implies \int \frac{dz}{z^2-1} = \int dx \\ \text{or } x &= \log\left\vert \ymx + \sqrt{\ymx^2 + 1}\right\vert + C \end{align} %text But as $y = 0$ when $x=0$, therefore $C = 0$. Hence, \[ \quad \underbrace{e^x = \ymx + \sqrt{\ymx^2 + 1}}_{\text{Answer}}\] %
